content:
Here is a tabular format summarizing the differences between indemnity and guarantee:

| Criteria | Indemnity | Guarantee |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Definition | An agreement in which one party promises to compensate the other party for any loss or damage incurred. | An agreement in which one party agrees to pay or discharge the debt or obligation of another party in case of default. |
| Nature | Primary liability | Secondary liability |
| Parties Involved | Two parties involved - indemnifier and indemnity holder | Three parties involved - creditor, principal debtor and surety |
| Purpose | To compensate for loss or damage incurred | To secure payment of debt or obligation |
| Triggering Event | Loss or damage incurred by the indemnity holder | Default by the principal debtor |
| Nature of Liability | Unlimited and uncapped liability | Limited liability, capped at the amount of guarantee |
| Requirement of Consideration | Consideration is not necessary | Consideration is necessary |
| Notice of Claim | Notice of claim is not necessary | Notice of default by the principal debtor is necessary |
| Termination | Terminates once the loss or damage has been compensated | Terminates once the debt or obligation has been discharged |

In summary, indemnity is an agreement in which one party agrees to compensate the other for any loss or damage incurred, while guarantee is an agreement in which one party agrees to pay or discharge the debt or obligation of another party in case of default. The parties involved, nature of liability, triggering event, and termination are also different for indemnity and guarantee.
